summaryParts.value: I'm not a developer ‚Äî but I've shipped five production apps anyway. I design systems, think through security, and collaborate with AI to bring ideas to life. It's a new way of building, and I'm all in. Featured by

paragraphs.label: Here's the thing:
paragraphs.text: I'm not a traditional developer. I can't whiteboard a binary tree or rattle off algorithms. But I've figured out something that works for me ‚Äî I design the system in my head, think through security and architecture, and then collaborate with AI tools to actually build it. It's like having a brilliant team that never sleeps, and my job is to be the one who knows what we're building and why.

paragraphs.label: It actually works.
paragraphs.text: I've shipped five production apps this way (the LuminOS suite), led a 72-hour infrastructure transformation when COVID hit, and somehow maintain a 98/100 average on SecurityScorecard. No dev team. Just me, some really good AI tools, and a lot of iteration. The site you're on right now? Same approach.

paragraphs.label: Security comes first, always.
paragraphs.text: Before I ask AI to generate anything, I've already thought through auth flows, rate limiting, secrets management, and what could go wrong. AI is powerful, but it needs guardrails. I'm the human in the loop ‚Äî the one who says 'wait, that's not secure enough' before it ships.

paragraphs.label: The toolkit:
paragraphs.text: Claude Code, Gemini CLI, Cursor IDE, MCP servers for orchestration. Usually multiple terminals running different agents for different parts of the system. It sounds chaotic, but there's a rhythm to it. Design, direct, review, ship, iterate.

paragraphs.label: The unlikely path:
paragraphs.text: I spent 12 years as a personal trainer and nutritionist before pivoting to IT in 2018. Joined GLAAD as help desk in 2019 and worked my way up to Associate IT Director. Turns out the discipline from bodybuilding ‚Äî showing up every day, tracking progress, iterating on what works ‚Äî translates pretty well to infrastructure and building software.

paragraphs.label: Gaming roots:
paragraphs.text: I used to be a competitive World of Warcraft raider and guild leader, theorycrafting strategies before guides existed. That systems thinking ‚Äî understanding how everything connects, optimizing under constraints, coordinating a team ‚Äî is honestly how I still approach problems today. Nerdier origin story than most, but it's mine.

commandCenter.intro: Yeah, it's a lot of screens. But when you're juggling AI agents, monitoring systems, and trying to ship something before the day ends, you need the real estate. This is where the work happens.

story.headline: 72-Hour Emergency Cloud Transformation During COVID-19
paragraphs: When COVID hit, I was still pretty new to IT. The MSP had just been let go, and suddenly I was looking at a legacy stack that needed to become fully remote in 72 hours. No consultants coming to save the day. Just me, a lot of coffee, and the realization that if I didn't figure this out, people couldn't do their jobs. So I figured it out.

GLAAD Media Awards (2019-Present): I handle IT infrastructure and security for the bi-annual flagship events in LA and NYC. In 2020, we had to pivot the entire thing to virtual broadcast with almost no lead time ‚Äî streaming infrastructure, security, production support. It was chaos, but good chaos.

legacy.title: üìã The Starting Point
legacy.intro: When I joined, the organization had recently relocated from LA to NYC, but the IT infrastructure hadn't fully made that transition. Like many nonprofits, years of rapid growth had outpaced technology investments. Here's what needed modernization:
items: Aging on-prem infrastructure managed by an external MSP
Limited documentation and internal visibility into systems
Authentication and identity management needed strengthening
Email and storage systems hitting capacity constraints
Device management was informal ‚Äî no centralized MDM
Phone systems weren't designed for remote work
Core infrastructure was location-dependent, not cloud-ready
Backup and disaster recovery needed formalization
Security controls required modernization across the board

luminos.title: ü§ñ LuminOS: The Apps I Built
luminos.intro: This is the part I'm most proud of. Five production apps, all built by collaborating with AI. I designed each system, obsessed over the security, and worked with Claude/Gemini to actually build them. Each app has its own AI persona that knows the domain ‚Äî Aegis for security, Astraea for finance, etc. The naming scheme? GLAAD is a light pillar for LGBTQ rights, so everything follows the 'light reveals truth' metaphor.
items: Diffract: Executive security dashboard ‚Äî real-time threat intel
Refract: Salesforce + NetSuite analytics ‚Äî financial intelligence
Prism: Media monitoring ‚Äî IGDB, TMDB, Dash Social, Reddit, OpenMeasures
Spectrum: Exploratory analysis ‚Äî pattern recognition and insight discovery
NetRunner: Desktop legal analysis ‚Äî Electron app with secure local processing
AI personas: Aegis, Astraea, LUMOS, IRIS, Turing
securityItems: Web apps hosted on Firebase Hosting + GCP Functions
Secrets stored in Firebase Secret Manager
Server-side OAuth token exchange (no client secrets in desktop app)
Firebase Auth enforcement with domain/allowlist controls
JumpCloud SSO with org-wide MFA across internal apps
Rate limiting, abuse detection, and model fallbacks on all AI endpoints

team.headline: Small Team, Big Output
team.body: It's me and a junior technician for day-to-day support ‚Äî that's the IT department. No developers on staff. Every app in LuminOS was designed and shipped by me using AI tools. I also help out with creative and media production for events, because at a nonprofit, you wear a lot of hats.

Zero-trust-aligned architecture with monthly pen test validation

projects.title: LuminOS
projects.description: Five apps that actually get used every day at GLAAD ‚Äî security, finance, media intelligence, and legal analysis. All built by me and AI working together. I'm genuinely proud of this one.

highlights: Five production apps delivered without a development team

Enterprise integrations: Salesforce, NetSuite, AWS, Proofpoint, and more

details.title: How It Was Built
items: Zero traditional development. Every component was architected by me and implemented by AI agents.
Multi-terminal workflows: different agents handle frontend, backend, infrastructure, and security review.
I specify requirements, security constraints, and architecture. AI generates code. I review, validate, and ship.
Each app has extensive guardrails: rate limiting, abuse detection, model fallbacks, and strict auth.

items: Diffract: Security dashboard with real-time threat intel from AWS WAF, Proofpoint, CrowdStrike

details.title: Naming Philosophy
items: GLAAD is a light pillar for LGBTQ rights; the suite follows how light reveals truth.

Spectrum: scans the landscape to separate noise from insight

Firebase Auth + Secrets Manager; App Check where supported
Electron desktop app with secure local processing and server-side token exchange

projects.title: Diffract

details.title: Purpose & How I Built It
items: Needed an executive security cockpit with red/green narrative of risk and readiness.
Designed the data model, API structure, and UI layout. Directed AI to implement each layer.
Specified security requirements upfront: auth flows, CORS policy, secrets handling, cache strategies.
Aegis AI persona translates complex security signals into actionable guidance.

details.title: Architecture
items: React + Vite frontend on Firebase Hosting; Python 3.12 Cloud Functions backend.
Vertex AI Gemini 3 Flash primary with 2.5 Flash fallback; lazy init to reduce cold starts.
Integrations: AWS WAF, Proofpoint, At-Bay (Gmail label scan), Google Drive.

details.title: Data Flow
items: User logs in via Firebase Auth; backend verifies ID token and @glaad.org domain on every call.
get_dashboard_data aggregates cache-first metrics (WAF 15 min, Proofpoint 5 min, At-Bay 6h, Drive 60 min).
Aegis chat validates auth and App Check, injects dashboard context, returns AI response with fallback.

details.title: Security Guardrails
items: Strict CORS allowlist, App Check (warn mode), secrets in Firebase Secret Manager.
Layout locked to h-screen + overflow-hidden to prevent content jump.
Hosting headers set no-cache for index.html to prevent stale deploys.

details.title: Architecture
items: React + Vite + TypeScript frontend; Python 3.12 Cloud Functions backend.

details.title: Security & Operations
items: Allowlist enforced in two layers: frontend ALLOWED_EMAILS and backend ALLOWED_USERS secret.
Deep Research runs async with status polling; fallback to Gemini Flash if Perplexity fails.
CSP report-only headers plus /csp-report endpoint for visibility.
External links sanitized to http(s) only; upload guardrails for crafted-PDF risk.

details.title: How I Built This Site
items: Designed component architecture, content model, and visual system.

details.title: Technical Architecture
items: React 18 + TypeScript + Vite on Cloudflare Pages.
Cloudflare Worker proxies Gemini API with 3-layer rate limiting and abuse detection.
Canvas particle system with spatial grid optimization and visibility-aware pausing.
Content centralized in site.json for easy updates without code changes.

details.title: Security Implementation
items: CSP: strict-src 'self' only; HSTS: 2 years, preload.
Rate limiting: 250 requests/month per IP + session + global.
30-second cooldown between AI requests; 6-strike abuse = 30-minute ban.
HttpOnly, Secure, SameSite=Strict session cookies.
